Chief Complaint:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   A 68 year old gentleman was transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] (scheduled for floor
   admission) from [**Hospital 11374**] Community Hospital at the request of his
   family for ongoing pneumonia not improving with Abx.  There was also
   being treated for afib, ?CHF  and possible UE DVT. Head CT normal
   there.  Echo there with ? TV vegetation, normal EF.  During the Medivac
   (per flow sheet): patient ambulatory prior to flight.  During the
   flight he was in Afib, satting 96-100% on 3L NC.  Never hypotensive or
   tachycardic. BS varied from 81-441 (pre/post dextrose administration).
   Patient became confused ~16:15. His rate increased to 110-130  ~ 17:00,
   labelled as ? for which he received 100mg Lidocaine, presumably IV just
   prior to arrival at [**Hospital1 1**].  After deplaning from a medivac flight, the
   patient became unresponsive and was transferred to the [**Hospital1 1**] emergency
   room.
   In the ED, vital signs were initially: 96.9 69 180/84 12 100% NRB.
   Patient was intubated for airway protection given unresponsiveness
   (Etomidate & Succ for intubation; Propofol for sedation).  He was given
   Vanc/Zosyn for HAP vs. abdominal process. BS in the 70s, given D50
   without change in mental status.  Transferred to the MICU: 96.4 120/59
   14 100% 500/14/10/1.0.
   On arrival to the floor, the patient is not responsive to voice or
   sternal rub.  His family is present and confirm the hospital course.
   Per all reports, he was independent at home and still working but
   "slowing down" recently with weight loss, several recent
   hospitalizations for pneumonia.  His rapid change in status today was
   unexpected and not at all resembling his recent hospital course.
   24 Hour Events:

   Alb 2.9  Tox screen neg. UA neg   TSH 1.3
   Abd CT: possible vegetation on tricuspid valve.  Density in liover
   suspicious for malignancy, consider MRI for further eval.
   Assessment and Plan
   A 68 yo gentleman with progressive decline transferred from [**Location (un) 11374**]
   after PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status during/after
   [**Location (un) 1045**].
   .
   #. Altered Mental Status: The patient has underlying dementia as
   evidenced by family &  recent notes. His acute decline midflight
   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine
   administration.  Seizure vs. anoxic brain injury at altitude/arrythmia,
   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently
   improving, making anoxic injury less likely.
   - lighten sedation
   - Echo to eval vegitation/clot
   - LP if no improvement
   - Obtain OSH CSF results
   - TSH normal
   - plan to extubated if no need for TEE
   .
   #. PNA: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a
   presumed aspiration PNA over the past 2 weeks. Not febrile, no
   leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet
   cleared.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn now
   - plan to extubated once clear that TEE not needed
   - Blood Cx, Sputum Cx
   - F/U OSH Micro
   - legionella urinary antigen negative
   .
   #. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired
   shivering given mental status. Now improved
   - Warming blanket overnight, now off
   - Cultures as above
   .
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure"
   based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure.
   - Fluid rescusitation
   - Monitor UOP, which is currently improved
   .
   #. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars, but has been
   requiring glucose for hypoglycemia overnight
   - Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN
   - Tube feeds
   .
   #. ? RUE DVT: Currently therpeutic INR, U/S results not in records
   - Obtain outside records
   - Repeat RUE U/S
   - Transition to heparin drip if INR <2
   .
   #. Sick Sinus: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate controlled
   without medications, received Lidocaine in transit.
   - Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled (currently in 60
   - Cardiac Enzymes, 3^rd set today
   -continue ASA
   #? Cardiac valve vegetation:  seen at OSH, and on CT here.  Getting TTE
   today.  Unclear if infected vegetation vs other cause (clot,
   neoplasm).  Will follow up TTE to eval if needs TEE.  Follow up blood
   cultures.
   #. Cerebral Ventricular Dilitation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain
   further symptom history from family.  MS currently improved from
   yesterday
   .
   #. G-tube placement for ? esophagitis:  Will contact team in [**Name (NI) 490**]
   re: need for G-tube, in patient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal
   issues, speech and swallow once awake.
   - start Tube feeds, nutrition recs
   -clarify degree of esophagitis
   .
   #. Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency
   - Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear
   # liver lesion on CT:  no acute issue.  Will follow up with MRI when
   clinically stable
   .
   #. CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves
   - Hold metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypertension: Borderline BPs
   - Hold lisinopril/metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO Daily
   .
   #. Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / tube feeds
   # PPX: H2 blocker, Therapeutic Coumadin & boots, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: PIV x2
   # CODE:  Full, discussed with patient's wife
   # CONTACT:  Wife [**Name (NI) 11376**] C: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11377**], H (daughter): [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11378**];
   H: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11379**]
   # ICU CONSENT: Signed
   # DISPOSITION:
    [X] ICU
   Total time spent:  45 min

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, possible chronic heart failure, and possible upper extremity deep vein thrombosis. He was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department due to altered mental status, which occurred during a medivac flight. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 125/59 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, troponin level, and C-reactive protein, indicating an inflammatory response. 

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's underlying conditions and laboratory results, there is a risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation, possible cardiac valve vegetation, and cardiac enzyme elevations increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status, which occurred during the medivac flight, may be related to anoxic brain injury, seizure, or septic emboli. There is a risk of further neurological decline or complications, such as cerebral edema or hemorrhage.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with mechanical ventilation and a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a gastrostomy tube in place, which may be necessary for nutrition and hydration. There is a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, obstruction, or infection.
6. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia, which may be due to iron deficiency or chronic disease, requires further evaluation and management.
7. Endocrine complications: The patient's hypothyroidism requires continued levothyroxine replacement therapy.
8. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential dehydration increase the risk of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics for presumed aspiration pneumonia, fluid resuscitation, and management of his underlying conditions. Further evaluation and management are needed to address the patient's potential medical complications and optimize his care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency room due to progressive decline and acute change in mental status during and after a medivac flight. The patient has a history of pneumonia, and his rapid decline in mental status is unexpected and not resembling his recent hospital course.

The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of atrial flutter and was given lidocaine during the flight, which may have contributed to his altered mental status.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.1 K/uL
* Hct: 28.0%
* Plt: 543
* Cr: 0.6 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 38 mmHg
* Glucose: 41 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Altered Mental Status: Daily wake-up to assess mental status, EEG, echo to evaluate vegetation/clot, and LP if no improvement.
* PNA: Continue Vanc/Zosyn, respiratory support, and blood cultures.
* Hypothermia: Warming blanket and cultures.
* Metabolic Alkalosis: Permissive hypercapnia, fluid resuscitation, and monitor UOP.
* Diabetes Mellitus: Reduce home Lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN, and tube feeds.
*? RUE DVT: Obtain outside records, repeat RUE U/S, and transition to heparin drip if INR <2.
* Sick Sinus: Hold metoprolol/diltiazem, rate-controlled, and cardiac enzymes.
* Ventricular Dilitation: Obtain further symptom history from family.
* G-tube placement for? esophagitis: Start tube feeds and nutrition recommendations.
* Anemia: Iron, B12, Folate, retic count, and smear.
* CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves, and hold metoprolol.
* Hypertension: Hold lisinopril/metoprolol.
* Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO daily.
* Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Seizure or anoxic brain injury due to atrial flutter or lidocaine administration.
* Sepsis or septic shock due to pneumonia or other underlying infections.
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or other lung conditions.
* Cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
* Gastrointestinal complications such as esophagitis, pancreatitis, or bowel obstruction.
* Endocrine complications such as hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency.
* Hematological complications such as anemia or bleeding disorders.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 68-year-old gentleman, was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department (ED) with a rapid decline in mental status during a medivac flight. He was previously admitted to another hospital for pneumonia not improving with antibiotics and was also being treated for atrial fibrillation, possible congestive heart failure (CHF), and upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's condition has been complex, with multiple potential medical complications arising. These include:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient has underlying dementia, and his acute decline during the medivac flight may be related to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine administration. Seizure, anoxic brain injury, clot, or septic emboli showering from possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve are potential causes.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a presumed aspiration pneumonia (PNA) over the past two weeks. Not febrile, no leukocytosis, and possible old PNA not yet cleared on CXR findings.
3. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis, hypothyroidism, or impaired shivering given mental status. Now improved.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure" based on CXR findings, although unclear if he has heart failure. Fluid resuscitation and monitoring of urine output are necessary.
5. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars, requiring glucose for hypoglycemia overnight. Reduce home Lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN, and tube feeds.
6.?RUE DVT: Currently therapeutic INR, U/S results not in records. Obtain outside records, repeat RUE U/S, and transition to heparin drip if INR <2.
7. Sick Sinus: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate-controlled without medications, received lidocaine in transit. Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate-controlled (currently in 60-70 beats per minute).
8. Cardiac valve vegetation: Seen at outside hospital and on CT here. Getting TTE today to evaluate if infected vegetation or other cause (clot, neoplasm). Follow-up blood cultures.
9. Cerebral Ventricular Dilitation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain further symptom history from family. MS currently improved from yesterday.
10. G-tube placement for? esophagitis: Will contact team regarding need for G-tube, inpatient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal issues, speech, and swallow once awake.
11. Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency. Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear necessary.
12. CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves. Hold metoprolol.
13. Hypertension: Borderline BPs. Hold lisinopril/metoprolol.
14. Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO daily.
15. Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds.
16. FEN: IVFs, replete lytes PRN, and tube feeds.
17. PPX: H2 blocker, therapeutic Coumadin & boots, bowel regimen.
18. ACCESS: PIV x2.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: 96.4F, 120/59 mmHg, 14 breaths per minute, 100% oxygen saturation
* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation, PEEP 5 cmH2O, FiO2 40%
* Laboratory results: WBC 8.1 K/uL, Hct 28.0%, Plt 543 K/uL, Cr 0.6 mg/dL, TropT 0.04 ng/mL, TCO2 38 mmHg, Glucose 41 mg/dL
* Imaging studies: Possible vegetation on tricuspid valve on CT, density in liver suspicious for malignancy
* Plan: Continue antibiotics, lighten sedation, obtain OSH CSF results, and consider LP if no improvement. Monitor for sepsis, hypothyroidism, and impaired shivering. Consider TEE and TSH levels.

   - Warming blanket

   exposure to steroids, unable to compensate because of mechanical
   ventilation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency room due to a rapid decline in mental status. He has a history of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible chronic heart failure, and was being treated with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's condition has rapidly deteriorated, with a sudden onset of altered mental status, confusion, and increased heart rate. He was intubated for airway protection and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and atrial fibrillation increase his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and possible tricuspid valve vegetation increase his risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory compromise due to pneumonia and mechanical ventilation increases his risk of developing respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
4. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's hyperventilation and possible diuresis due to heart failure increase his risk of developing metabolic alkalosis, which can lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, and other complications.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's variable blood sugars and possible insulin resistance increase his risk of developing hypoglycemia, which can be life-threatening.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's possible esophagitis and chronic pancreatitis increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's possible chronic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and possible tricuspid valve vegetation increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or myocardial infarction.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's possible anoxic brain injury or seizure disorder increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke, cerebral edema, or seizures.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic status. He also requires further evaluation and treatment for his underlying conditions, including pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible chronic heart failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department due to acute changes in mental status during a medivac flight. He has a history of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible chronic heart failure. On arrival, he was intubated for airway protection and was found to have a rapid change in mental status, with a blood glucose level of 441 mg/dL and a heart rate of 110-130 beats per minute.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.5C
* Heart rate: 65-67 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 125/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He is sedated and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 12.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 28.0%
* Platelet count: 543 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 41 mg/dL
* Glucose: 41 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes:

* Pneumonia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Possible chronic heart failure
* Chronic pancreatitis
* Hypothyroidism
* Diabetes mellitus
*? Right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's rapid change in mental status and laboratory results suggest possible sepsis. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, and further evaluation is needed to determine the source of infection.
2. Cardiac valve vegetation: The patient's echocardiogram shows possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve, which may be infected. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the vegetation and to plan appropriate treatment.
3. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's rapid change in mental status and laboratory results suggest possible anoxic brain injury. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the injury and to plan appropriate treatment.
4. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's laboratory results show metabolic alkalosis, which may be due to diuresis or hyperventilation. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the alkalosis and to plan appropriate treatment.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's laboratory results show hypothyroidism, which may be due to underlying thyroid disease or medication. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the hypothyroidism and to plan appropriate treatment.
6. Chronic pancreatitis: The patient's medical history includes chronic pancreatitis, which may be contributing to his symptoms. Further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the pancreatitis and to plan appropriate treatment.
7.? Right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's medical history includes possible right upper extremity DVT, which may be contributing to his symptoms. Further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the DVT and to plan appropriate treatment.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and further evaluation to determine the cause of his acute changes in mental status and to plan appropriate treatment.

   HPI:
   A 68 year old gentleman was transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] (scheduled for floor
   admission) from [**Hospital 11374**] Community Hospital at the request of his
   family for ongoing pneumonia.  During the Medivac (per flow sheet):
   patient ambulatory prior to flight.  During the flight he was in Afib,
   satting 96-100% on 3L NC.  Never hypotensive or tachycardic. BS varied
   from 81-441 (pre/post dextrose administration).  Patient became
   confused ~1615. His rate increased to 110 ~ 1700, labelled as ? for
   which he received 100mg Lidocaine, presumably IV just prior to arrival
   at [**Hospital1 1**].  After deplaning from a medivac flight, the patient became
   unresponsive and was transferred to the [**Hospital1 1**] emergency room.
   .
   In the ED, vital signs were initially: 96.9 69 180/84 12 100% NRB.
   Patient was intubated for airway protection given unresponsiveness
   (Etomidate & Succ for intubation; Propofol for sedation).  He was given

   Recommend echocardiogram. No pulmonary embolus or acute aortic
   abnormality.
   2. Left upper and lower lobe pneumonia. Bilateral pleural effusions,
   small

   concerning for biliary or hepatic neoplasm. This can be further

   cysts. These can be further assessed via MRI, if obtained to evaluate
   the

   A 68 yo gentleman with progressive decline transferred from [**Location (un) 11374**]
   after PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status during/after
   [**Location (un) 1045**].
   #. Altered Mental Status: The patient has underlying dementia as
   evidenced by family &  recent notes. His acute decline midflight
   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine
   administration.  Seizure vs. anoxic brain injury at altitude/arrythmia,
   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently
   unresponsive and intubated for airway protection.
   - Daily wake up to assess mental status
   - EEG in AM
   - Echo to eval vegitation/clot
   - LP if no improvement
   - Obtain OSH CSF results
   - TSH
   - Check Ammonia
   #. PNA: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a
   presumed aspiration PNA over the past 2 weeks. Not febrile, no
   leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet
   cleared.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn now
   - Respiratory support as above until mental status clears
   - Blood Cx, Sputum Cx
   - F/U OSH Micro
   - Add on legionella urinary antigen
   #. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired
   shivering given mental status.
   - Warming blanket
   - Cultures
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure"
   based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure.  No
   exposure to steroids, unable to compensate because of mechanical
   ventilation.
   - Permissive hypercapnia
   - Fluid rescusitation
   - Monitor UOP
   #. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars
   - Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN
   - Tube feeds
   #. ? RUE DVT: Currently therpeutic INR, U/S results not in records
   - Obtain outside records
   - Repeat RUE U/S
   - Transition to heparin drip if INR <2
   #. Sick Sinus: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate controlled
   without medications, received Lidocaine in transit.
   - Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled
   - Cardiac Enzymes
   #. Ventricular Dilitation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain further
   symptom history from family.
   #. G-tube placement for ? esophagitis:  Will contact team in [**Name (NI) 490**]
   re: need for G-tube, in patient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal
   issues, speech and swallow once awake.
   - start Tube feeds, nutrition recs
   #. Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency
   - Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear
   #. CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves
   - Hold metoprolol
   #. Hypertension: Borderline BPs
   - Hold lisinopril/metoprolol

   #. Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has a history of dementia, and his acute decline is suspected to be related to a rapid ventricular rate, lidocaine administration, and possible septic emboli. He is currently intubated and unresponsive. The patient's condition is complex, and multiple medical complications are possible.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's altered mental status, septic shock is a possibility. Monitoring for signs of sepsis, such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension, is essential.
2. Endocarditis: The patient has a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve, which may lead to further complications, such as heart failure, embolization, or abscess formation.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has left upper and lower lobe pneumonia, which may worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been variable, and hypoglycemia is a possibility, especially given his altered mental status.
5. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which may be related to his respiratory status, diuresis, or other underlying conditions.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, and his current condition may be exacerbating his symptoms.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to chronic disease, iron deficiency, or other underlying conditions.
8. Chronic Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis, which may lead to complications such as malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, or sepsis.
9. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is complex, and cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial flutter, may worsen his condition.
10. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's esophageal status is unclear, and gastrointestinal complications, such as esophagitis, may occur.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for endocarditis and pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and respiratory status closely.
3. Manage the patient's blood glucose levels carefully to prevent hypoglycemia.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluids and medications as needed.
5. Consider further imaging studies, such as MRI or CT scans, to evaluate the patient's liver and biliary tract status.
6. Consult with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac management.
7. Consider placement of a gastrostomy tube to ensure adequate nutrition and hydration.
8. Monitor the patient's wound status and consider wound care measures as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with a history of progressive decline, altered mental status, pneumonia, and possible endocarditis. He has been treated with various antibiotics for a presumed aspiration pneumonia over the past two weeks. The patient has underlying dementia and is currently unresponsive and intubated for airway protection. He has a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve, and there is concern for sepsis, hypothyroidism, and impaired shivering.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.1
* Hct: 28.0
* Plt: 543
* Cr: 0.6
* TropT: 0.04
* TCO2: 38
* Glucose: 41

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CTA Chest and CT abd/pelvis with contrast:
	+ 13 mm soft tissue density nodule along the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, concerning for infective endocarditis
	+ Left upper and lower lobe pneumonia
	+ Bilateral pleural effusions
	+ Left hepatic lobe atrophy and central biliary ductal dilatation
	+ Intermediate density right renal lesions
	+ Retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy
	+ Small amount of fluid layering posteriorly in the pelvis
* ECHO (Fellow study):
	+ Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets
	+ Trace aortic regurgitation
	+ Severe mitral annular calcification
	+ Probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count and CRP, indicating possible sepsis.
2. Endocarditis: The patient has a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve, which is a concerning finding.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level is elevated, indicating possible hypothyroidism.
4. Impaired shivering: The patient's mental status is altered, and he is unresponsive, which may indicate impaired shivering.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient has pneumonia and bilateral pleural effusions, which may lead to respiratory failure.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve and severe mitral annular calcification, which may lead to cardiac complications.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating possible renal failure.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, indicating possible hepatic failure.
9. Anemia: The patient's Hct level is low, indicating possible anemia.
10. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline high, indicating possible hypertension.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy accordingly.
3. Consider performing an EEG to assess the patient's neurological status.
4. Order a CT scan or MRI to further evaluate the patient's liver and kidneys.
5. Consider performing a liver biopsy to evaluate the patient's liver function.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy accordingly.
7. Consider performing a pulmonary artery catheterization to assess the patient's cardiac function.
8. Monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust therapy accordingly.
9. Consider performing a thyroid function test to evaluate the patient's thyroid status.
10. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, aspiration, altered mental status, and hypoglycemia. The patient has a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, chronic pancreatitis, and CAD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T: 36.7C (98.1F), HR: 65 bpm, BP: 101/50 mmHg, RR: 15 inspirations per minute, SpO2: 100%
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube with CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow ventilation, FiO2: 40%, PEEP: 5 cmH2O, RSBI: 82
* Cardiovascular system: Paced, with a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve
* Neurological system: Sedated, responding to commands, able to move all extremities
* Renal function: Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL, BUN: 19 mg/dL
* Hepatic function: Bilirubin: 1.2 mg/dL, ALT: 27 IU/L
* Coagulation profile: INR: 2.6, aPTT: 40.1 seconds
* Blood cultures: Positive for Legionella, pending results

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of endocarditis and pneumonia, which increases the risk of developing sepsis.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a history of DVT and is currently receiving therapeutic anticoagulation.
4. Liver lesions: The patient has liver lesions on CT scan, which may be indicative of liver disease or neoplasm.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic inflammation.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had episodes of hypoglycemia and is currently receiving treatment for diabetes mellitus.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is receiving treatment with levothyroxine.
8. Chronic pancreatitis: The patient has chronic pancreatitis and is receiving treatment with Creon.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing treatment for endocarditis and pneumonia
2. Monitoring for sepsis and VAP
3. Managing DVT prophylaxis and treatment
4. Evaluating liver lesions with triphasic CT of liver
5. Transfusing if HCT < 21
6. Restarting statin once cleared by cardiology
7. Continuing metoprolol
8. Managing hypertension with home metoprolol
9. Monitoring for hypoglycemia and adjusting treatment as necessary
10. Continuing treatment for hypothyroidism
11. Managing chronic pancreatitis with Creon
12. Providing nutrition support with tube feeds and fiber supplementation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was intubated on arrival and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 332 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 79%. He has a history of atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response, which is being rate-controlled with lidocaine.

The patient's respiratory status has improved overnight, with a decrease in ventilator settings. However, he still has significant pulmonary and pleural disease with clinical pneumonia, which is being treated empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.

The patient has a tricuspid valve vegetation, which is being monitored with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE). He also has left upper extremity swelling, which is being evaluated with an ultrasound.

The patient has a history of malignancy, erosive esophagitis, and liver lesions, which are being further evaluated with imaging studies. He is also being treated for anemia, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). His nutritional needs are being met with a fiber-rich diet and glycemic control is being maintained with regular insulin sliding scale.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia is being treated empirically, but it is essential to monitor for any signs of progression, such as increased respiratory distress or hemodynamic instability.
2. Tricuspid valve vegetation: The patient's tricuspid valve vegetation can lead to complications such as endocarditis, valve failure, or embolic events.
3. Left upper extremity swelling: The patient's left upper extremity swelling can be a sign of deep vein thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism or other complications.
4. Liver lesions: The patient's liver lesions can be a sign of liver dysfunction or cancer, which can lead to complications such as jaundice, ascites, or bleeding.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased tolerance to medications.
6. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to hemodynamic instability, decreased cardiac output, or embolic events.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can lead to complications such as cardiac failure, renal failure, or cerebral hemorrhage.
8. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis can lead to complications such as muscle weakness, fatigue, or decreased cardiac output.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjusting his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman transferred from another hospital with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a history of malignancy, tricuspid vegetation, and liver lesions. His laboratory results show anemia, mild hypocalcemia, and mild hypomagnesemia. He is receiving antibiotic treatment and has a plan to pursue further imaging studies.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia progression:** The patient's pneumonia is not improving, and there is a risk of further progression, which could lead to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. **Tricuspid vegetation:** The presence of a tricuspid vegetation increases the risk of endocarditis and potential sepsis, which could lead to further complications and poor outcomes.
3. **LUE swelling:** The patient's left upper extremity swelling may indicate deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, which requires further evaluation and management.
4. **Aspiration risk:** The patient's history of erosive esophagitis and gastrointestinal tube feeds increases the risk of aspiration, which could lead to respiratory compromise and potential death.
5. **Liver lesions:** The patient's liver lesions may be indicative of liver disease or metastases, which could impact his overall prognosis and treatment options.
6. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may be caused by acute bleeding, iron deficiency, or anemia of chronic disease, which requires further evaluation and management.
7. **Afib/SSS:** The patient's atrial fibrillation and supraventricular tachycardia may increase his risk of stroke and other cardiovascular complications.
8. **Met alkalosis:** The patient's met alkalosis may require further evaluation and management to prevent potential complications such as seizures and cardiac arrhythmias.

These potential complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's condition to prevent further deterioration and improve his outcomes.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, aspiration, and altered mental status. The patient has undergone various procedures, including a transesophageal echocardiogram, thoracentesis, and placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 65 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 98/82 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 95% on a nasal cannula, and his respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypoalbuminemia. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, and his troponin level is 0.04 ng/mL.

The patient's medical history includes diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic kidney disease. He is taking various medications, including metformin, lisinopril, and levothyroxine.

The patient's current medications include piperacillin-tazobactam, vancomycin, and famotidine. He is also receiving tube feeds and has a PEG tube in place.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of endocarditis and pneumonia increases his risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and his oxygen saturation is slightly decreased, which may indicate respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and his current cardiac enzymes may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and his current laboratory results may increase his risk of developing renal failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and his current medications may increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued antibiotic therapy for endocarditis and pneumonia.
2. Monitoring of his respiratory status and oxygen saturation.
3. Management of his cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels.
5. Management of his gastrointestinal symptoms and risk of bleeding.
6. Continued tube feeds and nutritional support.
7. Monitoring of his mental status and potential for delirium.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has undergone several procedures, including a transesophageal echocardiogram, thoracentesis, and placement of a PICC line. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/82 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and creatinine levels, indicating possible sepsis and kidney damage. His troponin-T level is elevated, suggesting possible cardiac damage. His glucose level is fluctuating, and he has received insulin and dextrose infusions to manage his blood sugar levels.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to his altered mental status and lack of cooperation. His neurologic examination is also limited, but he responds to verbal commands and moves spontaneously.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 95%. He is receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula and has been extubated successfully.

The patient's medical history is significant for previous radiation therapy, erosive esophagitis, and a tricuspid valve vegetation. He has a cardiologist who is concerned about the vegetation and would like period updates.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to the endocarditis and pneumonia.
2. Cardiac damage and heart failure due to the tricuspid valve vegetation and possible cardiac damage from the endocarditis.
3. Respiratory failure due to the pneumonia and possible aspiration.
4. Neurologic complications due to the altered mental status and possible sepsis.
5. Kidney damage and acute kidney injury due to the elevated creatinine levels.
6. Hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia due to the fluctuating glucose levels.
7. Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to the patient's immobility and possible hypercoagulability.
8. Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's altered mental status and possible sepsis.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his conditions to prevent and treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing progressive decline, altered mental status, and acute change in mental status during/after a pneumonia episode. He has been diagnosed with endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. The patient is currently extubated and has a tracheostomy tube in place. He has a history of cardiac issues, including atrial fibrillation, and has been prescribed anticoagulation therapy. The patient's liver function is abnormal, and he has been diagnosed with anemia of chronic inflammation. He has also been diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Embolization of the cardiac mass (myxoma or fibroelastoma)
	* Heart failure due to ventricular dilation
	* Thromboembolic events due to atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation therapy
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia and aspiration
	* Respiratory failure due to chronic pancreatitis
3. Neurological Complications:
	* Altered mental status due to hypoglycemia, sepsis, or medication
	* Increased risk of delirium due to prolonged ICU stay
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Esophagitis and aspiration due to tube feeding and G-tube placement
	* Malnutrition and dehydration due to inadequate nutrition and hydration
5. Hematological Complications:
	* Anemia due to chronic inflammation and bleeding
	* Thrombocytopenia due to anticoagulation therapy and sepsis
6. Liver Complications:
	* Hepatic dysfunction due to sepsis and anticoagulation therapy
	* Increased risk of liver failure due to chronic pancreatitis
7. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hypoglycemia due to diabetes and inadequate nutrition
	* Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate therapy and anticoagulation therapy

Recommendations:

1. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events
2. Monitor cardiac function and adjust therapy as needed
3. Manage respiratory status with oxygen therapy and non-invasive ventilation
4. Monitor neurological status and adjust therapy as needed
5. Manage gastrointestinal symptoms with antacids and H2 blockers
6. Monitor hematological status and adjust therapy as needed
7. Monitor liver function and adjust therapy as needed
8. Manage metabolic status with insulin and bicarbonate therapy
9. Consider cardiac surgery evaluation for possible resection of the cardiac mass
10. Consider liver biopsy to evaluate liver lesions.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman with a history of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has undergone several procedures, including a transesophageal echocardiogram, thoracentesis, and placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37C, HR 65 bpm, BP 98/82 mmHg, RR 23 inspirations per minute, SpO2 95%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 10 cmH2O, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) 30/15 mmHg, cardiac output (CO) 4.8 L/min
* Respiratory support: Oxygen therapy via nasal cannula, mechanical ventilation (MV) with a tidal volume (Vt) of 250 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 0 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%
* Laboratory results: White blood cell count (WBC) 8.1 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) 9.5 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) 610 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 46 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) 0.9 mg/dL, glucose 46 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a history of endocarditis, which can lead to further complications such as valve damage, abscesses, or embolization.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of pneumonia, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, or empyema.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has a diagnosis of altered mental status, which can be caused by a variety of factors such as sepsis, hypoxia, or medication side effects.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a diagnosis of hypoglycemia, which can lead to further complications such as seizures, coma, or even death if left untreated.
5. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has a diagnosis of metabolic alkalosis, which can lead to further complications such as muscle weakness, fatigue, or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Anemia: The patient has a diagnosis of anemia, which can lead to further complications such as fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased exercise tolerance.
7. Liver lesions: The patient has liver lesions on CT scan, which can be caused by a variety of factors such as liver disease, cancer, or infection.
8. Chronic pancreatitis: The patient has a diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis, which can lead to further complications such as pancreatitis, malnutrition, or diabetes.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to monitor him closely for any signs of deterioration and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 68-year-old gentleman, was transferred from the operating room (OSH) with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was extubated yesterday and had a thoracentesis, which removed 860cc of straw-colored fluid. The patient reported some confusion overnight, low blood glucose levels in the morning, and some wheezing. He denies shortness of breath or pain.

Physically, the patient appears thin and cachectic, with bilateral rhonchi on auscultation. His heart rate is irregular, and his abdomen is soft. There is no edema in his extremities.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 8.1 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 30.5%
* Platelet count (Plt): 610 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04
* ABG: 7.49/44/115/36/10

Radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Left lung infiltrates
* Echocardiogram (TTE): Partially mobile, smooth-walled mass on the septal and atrial side of the tricuspid valve, 1.6 cm in size; EF 55%, mild mitral stenosis, 1+ mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation gradient 32
* Left upper extremity ultrasound (LUE U/S): Pending

The patient is being treated empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for pneumonia, and the pleural fluid culture and cytology are pending. The patient has a tricuspid vegetation suspicious for a tumor, which warrants further intervention, possibly surgical management. He also has liver lesions on CT and esophageal stricture and erosions.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and acute respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
2. Tricuspid vegetation: The patient's tricuspid vegetation, suspected to be a tumor, may require further intervention, including surgical management.
3. Liver lesions: The patient's liver lesions may progress or worsen, potentially leading to liver failure or other complications.
4. Esophageal stricture and erosions: The patient's esophageal stricture and erosions may worsen, leading to further gastrointestinal complications.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac condition, including atrial fibrillation and tricuspid regurgitation, may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or other complications.
6. Infectious complications: The patient's pneumonia and other potential infections may worsen, leading to sepsis or other complications.
7. Nutritional complications: The patient's nutritional status, already compromised by his illness, may worsen, leading to further complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address his multiple medical conditions and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred from an outside hospital with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was extubated yesterday and had 860cc of straw-colored fluid removed via thoracentesis. He experienced some confusion overnight and low blood glucose levels this morning. He denies shortness of breath or pain.

The patient's medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. He is taking various medications, including metoprolol, albuterol, and warfarin, which was held due to an elevated INR.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 95.9F, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 140/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. His respiratory support includes a PSV/SBT ventilator mode with a tidal volume of 250 mL and a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute.

The patient's physical examination is significant for clear lung sounds on the right and rhonchorous sounds on the left, as well as mild edema in the lower extremities.

Laboratory results include:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 610 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* pH: 7.62
* Protein: 1.8 g/dL
* Glucose: 46 mg/dL
* LDH: 52 U/L

Imaging studies include a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showing a partially mobile smooth-walled mass on the septal and atrial side of the tricuspid valve, as well as a left upper extremity ultrasound pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Acute respiratory failure, which has resolved, but he still has significant pulmonary and pleural disease on the left.
* Treating empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, and completing a 14-day course.
* Following up on pleural fluid cultures and cytology.
* Performing a pulmonary toilet.
* Consulting with an outpatient pulmonologist.
* Suspecting a tricuspid vegetation, possibly due to a tumor, which may require surgical management.
* Discussing further intervention with the patient and family.
* Consulting with a cardiologist.
* Following up on left upper extremity swelling with a ultrasound.
* Managing esophageal stricture and erosions with tube feeds and swallow evaluation.
* Anticipating further imaging of liver lesions with triphasic CT.
* Providing renal protection with IV fluids and Mucomyst.
* Managing hypertension cautiously.
* Managing atrial fibrillation with rate control and heparin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia progression or recurrence
* Pleural effusion or empyema
* Tricuspid valve dysfunction or endocarditis
* Liver lesion progression or bleeding
* Renal impairment or failure
* Hypertension complications
* Atrial fibrillation complications, such as stroke or embolism
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation
* Nutritional deficiencies or malabsorption due to esophageal stricture and erosions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall, 63.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, and is being treated for shock, hypovolemic or hemorrhagic, endocarditis, hypoglycemia, altered mental status (not delirium), and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/49 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 430 mL, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an FiO2 of 40%. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, indicating an inflammatory response. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage. The patient's lactate level is elevated, indicating possible tissue hypoxia.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their altered mental status and inability to assess peripheral vascular, skin, and neurologic findings.

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and vasopressors. The patient's glucose level is within normal limits, but the patient's insulin infusion is not mentioned.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen or lead to other cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Septic shock: The patient's endocarditis and pneumonia may lead to septic shock.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated lactate level and possible cardiac damage may lead to renal failure.
5. Infection: The patient's endocarditis and pneumonia may lead to further infections.
6. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's coagulopathy and possible cardiac damage may lead to hemorrhagic complications.
7. Neurologic complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen or lead to neurologic complications.

The patient's code status is full code, indicating that the patient's family has opted for all life-sustaining measures to be used in the event of cardiac arrest.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of cardiac arrest. He has been receiving mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. He has also been diagnosed with pneumonia, aspiration, and endocarditis. His condition has been complicated by shock, hypovolemia, and altered mental status.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of pneumonia, aspiration, and endocarditis puts him at risk for sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and ongoing cardiac dysfunction may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and ongoing sedation may lead to neurological complications, such as delirium or seizures.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and sedation may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal complications: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and fluid management may lead to renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Hematological complications: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and blood product transfusions may lead to hematological complications, such as bleeding or thrombocytopenia.
8. Infection control: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of hospital-acquired infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) or catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs).

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition requires ongoing monitoring and management. The patient's mechanical ventilation and vasopressors should be adjusted as needed to maintain optimal blood pressure and oxygenation. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be continued and adjusted as necessary based on culture results. The patient's nutritional support should be optimized, and glycemic control should be maintained. The patient's lines and tubes should be monitored and maintained, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP should be continued. The patient's code status and disposition should be discussed with the family and documented in the medical record.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was admitted to the ICU after a PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status, recurrent aspiration PNA, and PEA arrest. He was intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, CAD, and diabetes mellitus. He is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and medications for his various comorbidities.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 97.5, HR 120, BP 130/80, RR 24, SpO2 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CO 5 L/min, CI 2.8 L/min/m2, mixed venous O2% sat 54-63
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CMV/ASSIST ventilator mode, Vt 430 mL, RR 24, PEEP 5 cmH2O, FiO2 40%
* Laboratory results: WBC 8.1, Hct 30.5, Plt 17.7, Cr 0.9, TropT 0.03, TCO2 34, Glucose 46

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is currently on antibiotics, which increases the risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and the PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 200, which may indicate respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of CAD and is currently on anticoagulants, which increases the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient has a history of altered mental status and is currently on sedation, which may lead to neurological deterioration.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is currently on antibiotics, which increases the risk of infection.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis and is currently on anticoagulants, which increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and is currently on insulin, which increases the risk of hypoglycemia.
8. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis and is currently on antibiotics, which increases the risk of renal failure.

Assessment and plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, and laboratory results.
* Continue to provide respiratory support with mechanical ventilation.
* Continue to provide antibiotic therapy for aspiration pneumonia.
* Continue to provide anticoagulant therapy for CAD.
* Continue to provide insulin therapy for diabetes mellitus.
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, neurological deterioration, infection, gastrointestinal bleeding, hypoglycemia, and renal failure.
* Consider adjusting the patient's medications and therapy based on his response to treatment and laboratory results.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's blood cultures are positive, and they have developed septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient has aspirated while being intubated, which has led to pneumonia. This can worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has had a cardiac arrest and is at risk for another one due to their underlying cardiac conditions.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and they are at risk for respiratory failure due to their pneumonia and septic shock.
5. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not properly managed.
6. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's lactate levels are elevated, which may indicate AKI. This is a potential complication of septic shock and requires close monitoring.
7. Hepatic Injury: The patient has a tricuspid valve mass, which may be related to their underlying liver disease. This could lead to hepatic injury and liver failure.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding due to their anticoagulation therapy.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient has altered mental status and is at risk for neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, or brain death.
10. Infection: The patient has multiple infections, including pneumonia, septicemia, and urinary tract infections, which can lead to further complications and organ failure.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring, aggressive management of their septic shock, and prompt treatment of their underlying conditions.

   on:[**2171-3-7**] 16:21 ------<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following information is summarized:

The patient, a 68-year-old man with a history of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) and remote mantle XRT, was readmitted to the MICU after a PEA arrest and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient has a history of recurrent aspiration, which led to the development of an esophageal stricture and subsequent PEG placement. The patient's current condition is critical, with respiratory failure, shock, and obtundation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7C (99.8F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 101/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Blood glucose: 46 mg/dL

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 17.7 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03 ng/mL
* TCO2: 34 mmHg
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* LDH: 302 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Echo: EF 40-45%, mild AR, mild MR, TV tumor mass, moderate TR, and RV dilation
* CT head: no acute process
* CXR: diffuse interstitial infiltrates
* CT triphasic liver: heterogenous liver; RP adenopathy

The patient's medical complications include:

* PEA arrest
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Shock (presumed septic shock)
* Obtundation
* Recurrent aspiration
* Hematuria
* Tricuspid valve mass
* Hepatic lesions
* Diarrhea
* Hypoglycemia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for aspiration pneumonia
* Fluid resuscitation for shock
* Weaning of norepinephrine
* Follow-up of ScvO2
* Conversion of G-tube to J-tube for aspiration
* Diuresis for pulmonary edema
* Holding of anticoagulation for hematuria
* Follow-up of CT scan of the liver for hepatic lesions
* Management of hypoglycemia

The patient's goals of care have been discussed with his family, and he has been made DNR/DNI due to his critical condition and uncertain long-term prognosis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL) and remote mantle XRT with subsequent esophageal stricture, recurrent aspiration after percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) on 02/26/2171. He was readmitted to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) after a PEA arrest and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing respiratory failure, shock, and obtundation. He is receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and sedation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a history of recurrent aspiration, which increases the risk of developing aspiration pneumonia.
3. Septic shock: The patient is presumed to have septic shock due to aspiration and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which increases the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can worsen with continued aspiration and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had repeated episodes of hypoglycemia, which can lead to further complications if not properly managed.
7. Infections: The patient has a history of infections, including C. difficile, which can worsen with continued immunosuppression.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen with continued hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
9. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac failure can worsen with continued hypoxemia and increased preload.
10. Organ dysfunction: The patient's multiple organ dysfunction can worsen with continued sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

In terms of the patient's current treatment plan, the following are notable:

1. Ventilator support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which is necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Vasopressors: The patient is receiving vasopressors to support blood pressure and perfusion.
3. Sedation: The patient is receiving sedation to manage agitation and discomfort.
4. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics to treat potential infections, including C. difficile.
5. Fluid resuscitation: The patient is receiving fluid resuscitation to support blood pressure and perfusion.
6. Nutrition: The patient is receiving nothing by mouth (NPO) to manage recurrent aspiration.
7. Glycemic control: The patient is receiving insulin sliding scale to manage hypoglycemia.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires ongoing close monitoring and management to address his multiple organ dysfunction and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of progressive decline, aspiration pneumonia, and cardiac arrest. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98.1F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 140/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.5-20.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.4-29.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 578-540 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-1.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03-0.04 ng/mL
* Blood glucose: 223-173 mg/dL

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including:

* Endocarditis
* Hypoglycemia
* Altered mental status
* Pneumonia
* Aspiration
* Chronic pancreatitis
* Erosive esophagitis
* Diabetes mellitus
* Anemia
* CAD
* Chronic kidney disease

The patient's medications include:

* Furosemide
* Vancomycin
* Piperacillin
* Pantoprazole
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Lantus
* Metoprolol
* ASA
* Heparin
* Creon
* Famotidine
* PPI

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuous EEG monitoring
* Periodic family meetings to discuss prognosis
* Weaning of sedation and analgesia
* Restarting of levophed
* Weaning of PEEP
* Restarting of warfarin
* Monitoring for infection and sepsis
* Monitoring for tricuspid valve mass and hepatic lesions
* Monitoring for hematuria
* Monitoring for diabetes and anemia
* Monitoring for CAD and chronic pancreatitis
* Monitoring for errosive esophagitis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Pancreatitis
* Esophageal perforation
* Hemorrhagic complications
* Infection
* Sepsis
* Organ failure

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's family has been informed of the patient's condition and the plan of care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, aspiration pneumonia, and acute change in mental status. The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis, erosive esophagitis, and diabetes mellitus.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98.1F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 140/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Arterial blood gas (ABG) results: pH 7.34, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) 49 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) 116 mmHg, bicarbonate (HCO3-) 25 mmol/L

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 12.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 578 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03 ng/mL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 25 mmol/L
* Glucose: 173 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
* Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating potential kidney damage.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose level is low, indicating potential hypoglycemic episodes.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, and he is at risk of developing delirium and decreased level of consciousness.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and VAP.
* Endocarditis: The patient has a high risk of developing endocarditis, which can lead to cardiac complications.
* Hepatic lesions: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis and erosive esophagitis, which can lead to hepatic lesions.
* Hematuria: The patient has a high risk of developing hematuria, which can lead to kidney damage and decreased kidney function.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous EEG monitoring to assess neurologic status
* Discontinuation of sedation and monitoring of neurologic status
* Holding tube feeds and monitoring of PaO2/FiO2 ratio
* Continuing vanc/zosyn and monitoring of respiratory status
* Weaning sedation and monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure
* Continuing levophed and monitoring of blood pressure
* Holding lopressor and monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old man who has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure and PEA arrest following aspiration pneumonia. The patient has shown improvement overnight, with a decrease in the amount of crackles in his lungs and a decrease in his need for pressors. He has been diuresed and has had his G-tube inserted.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.1F, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 122/58 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 13 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.5, a hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL, and a platelet count of 540 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medical history is significant for respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and a history of atrial fibrillation. He is currently on a variety of medications, including vancomycin, piperacillin, and fentanyl.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he does not continue to improve and if his oxygen saturation drops.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment, such as dialysis.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke or thromboembolism.
5. Contrast dye reaction: The patient's exposure to contrast dye may have caused a reaction, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Continue to provide oxygen therapy as needed to maintain the patient's oxygen saturation.
3. Continue to provide diuretic therapy as needed to manage the patient's fluid status.
4. Continue to provide antibiotics as needed to treat the patient's infection.
5. Consider the use of anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke or thromboembolism in the patient's atrial fibrillation.
6. Consider the use of dialysis to manage the patient's acute renal failure.
7. Consider the use of further evaluation and treatment for the patient's leukocytosis.
8. Consider the use of further evaluation and treatment for the patient's contrast dye reaction.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing progressive decline, including recurrent aspiration pneumonia and cardiac arrest. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 144/77 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 40%.

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including atrial fibrillation, shock, and endocarditis. He also has a history of diabetes mellitus, anemia, and chronic pancreatitis.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 17.7 x 10^9/L. His hemoglobin level is 9.3 g/dL, and his platelet count is 481 x 10^9/L. His creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, and his troponin-T level is 0.04 ng/mL.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, fentanyl, and midazolam. He is also receiving pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis and furosemide for fluid management.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing to hold tube feeds pending post-pyloric tube placement, attempting to wean vent settings, and continuing vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for 8 days. He will also receive stress ulcer prophylaxis and fluid management with furosemide.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 40%. He may require further adjustments to his ventilator settings or consideration of non-invasive ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently receiving lopressor to control his heart rate. He may require further adjustments to his medication regimen or consideration of cardioversion.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics for suspected endocarditis. He may require further evaluation and treatment for any underlying infections.
4. Hemorrhage: The patient has a history of hematuria and is receiving anticoagulation therapy. He may require further evaluation and treatment for any bleeding complications.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient has a history of chronic pancreatitis and may be at risk for hepatic failure. He may require further evaluation and treatment for any liver dysfunction.
6. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and may be at risk for renal failure. He may require further evaluation and treatment for any kidney dysfunction.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat any complications that may arise.
